# The `Value` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

A <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a> is an JSON value of unknown type. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Description {#details}

A <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a> is an JSON value of unknown type.

They can be copied, but should generally be moved.

=== Composing values ===

You can implicitly construct Values from:
<ul>
<li>strings: std::string, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallstring">SmallString</a>, formatv, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a>, char&#42; (char&#42;, and <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> are references, not copies!)</li>
<li>numbers</li>
<li>booleans</li>
<li>null: nullptr</li>
<li>arrays: &#123;&quot;foo&quot;, 42.0, false&#125;</li>
<li>serializable things: types with toJSON(const T&amp;)-&gt;<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a>, found by ADL</li>
</ul>


They can also be constructed from object/array helpers:
<ul>
<li><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/object">json::Object</a> is a type like map&lt;ObjectKey, Value&gt;</li>
<li><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/array">json::Array</a> is a type like vector&lt;Value&gt; These can be list-initialized, or used to build up collections in a loop. json::ary(Collection) converts all items in a collection to Values.</li>
</ul>


=== Inspecting values ===

Each <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a> is one of the JSON kinds: null (nullptr&#95;t) boolean (bool) number (double, int64 or uint64) string (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a>) array (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/array">json::Array</a>) object (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/object">json::Object</a>)

The kind can be queried directly, or implicitly via the typed accessors: if (std::optional&lt;StringRef&gt; S = E.getAsString() assert(E.kind() == <a href="#ad10d8b22abefa6faed2bdc37463da8b5a5ce030d664a66bc0d280f1231ff2cc5b">Value::String</a>);

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/array">Array</a> and <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/object">Object</a> also have typed indexing accessors for easy traversal: <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/expected">Expected&lt;Value&gt;</a> E = parse(R&quot;( &#123;&quot;options&quot;: &#123;&quot;font&quot;: &quot;sans-serif&quot;&#125;&#125; )&quot;); if (Object&#42; O = E-&gt;<a href="#a77428427461f125c633b3b81f9a72b9f">getAsObject()</a>) if (Object&#42; Opts = O-&gt;getObject(&quot;options&quot;)) if (std::optional&lt;StringRef&gt; Font = Opts-&gt;getString(&quot;font&quot;)) assert(Opts-&gt;at(&quot;font&quot;).<a href="#a994fb66ab65ca59d7843fa2b15f8b84a">kind()</a> == <a href="#ad10d8b22abefa6faed2bdc37463da8b5a5ce030d664a66bc0d280f1231ff2cc5b">Value::String</a>);

=== Converting JSON values to C++ types ===

The convention is to have a deserializer function findable via ADL: fromJSON(const json::Value&amp;, T&amp;, Path) -&gt; bool

The return value indicates overall success, and <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/path">Path</a> is used for precise error reporting. (The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/path/root">Path::Root</a> passed in at the top level fromJSON call captures any nested error and can render it in context). If conversion fails, fromJSON calls <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/path/#abb341982d84226c17deb044ca13eb048">Path::report()</a> and immediately returns. This ensures that the first fatal error survives.

Deserializers are provided for:
<ul>
<li>bool</li>
<li>int and int64&#95;t</li>
<li>double</li>
<li>std::string</li>
<li>vector&lt;T&gt;, where T is deserializable</li>
<li>map&lt;string, T&gt;, where T is deserializable</li>
<li>std::optional&lt;T&gt;, where T is deserializable <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/objectmapper">ObjectMapper</a> can help writing <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/json/#a46df0e111acfe74d856f9946d05faa4a">fromJSON()</a> functions for object types.</li>
</ul>


For conversion in the other direction, the serializer function is: toJSON(const T&amp;) -&gt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">json::Value</a> If this exists, then it also allows constructing <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a> from T, and can be used to serialize vector&lt;T&gt;, map&lt;string, T&gt;, and std::optional&lt;T&gt;.

=== Serialization ===

Values can be serialized to JSON: 1) <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/raw-ostream">raw&#95;ostream</a> &lt;&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a> // Basic formatting. 2) <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/raw-ostream">raw&#95;ostream</a> &lt;&lt; formatv(&quot;&#123;0&#125;&quot;, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a>) // Basic formatting. 3) <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/raw-ostream">raw&#95;ostream</a> &lt;&lt; formatv(&quot;&#123;0:2&#125;&quot;, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/json/value">Value</a>) // Pretty-print with indent 2.

And parsed: <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/expected">Expected&lt;Value&gt;</a> E = <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/json/#a15ac4901fb02274b34ca5df73bd40c25">json::parse</a>(&quot;&#91;1, 2, null&#93;&quot;); assert(E &amp;&amp; E-&gt;<a href="#a994fb66ab65ca59d7843fa2b15f8b84a">kind()</a> == <a href="#ae5050cd67e450419cf638e2a09bf11c9">Value::Array</a>);

Definition at line 288 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/json-h">JSON.h</a>.

### OStream {#aad0dd97fa8573ef1fddb02e5dc9754b7}
